title: Velocity vs time graph for dart and target

content.description: A student wants to launch a toy dart toward a target that hangs from a light string. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the dart is launched with an initial speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> at an angle <math alttext="theta sub 0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>Î¸</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> above the horizontal ground. At the instant the dart is launched, the string is cut such that the target begins to fall straight down. The positive horizontal direction is considered to be to the right, and the positive vertical direction is considered to be up.
content.question: Which of the following graphs could represent the vertical component of the velocity as a function of time for the dart and the target immediately after the dart is launched and the target begins to fall?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
